item.title: The Self-reflection of Shiny App
item.description:
Introduction and motivation

The first two posts have introduced the basic information of COVID-19 in Japan. Because the analytic directions of the posts were subjective, the figures and tables are determined and constant, which means they are generated based on the directions of the analysis. This type of table and figure might reduce the engagement of readers and cannot provide sufficient access for readers to further exploring the data. Therefore, a Shiny app of COVID-19 has been created to provide opportunities for readers to explore the situation of COVID-19 in their interested countries.

There are three countries available in the app currently, which are Japan, Australia, and the US. Meanwhile, the Shiny app contains three main sections. The first section is about, which introduces the basic information, like author and student ID, and the purpose of the app. The second section is app, which contains three subsections of explanation, figure, and table. The subsection of explanation provides an overview of the structure of the app, which might help users understand the functions of each section and get familiar with the app. Meanwhile, it provides the instructions of subsections of figure and table. The subsections of figure and table provide the chances for users to explore the information of COVID-19. Users could select the elements they are interested in, and the corresponding figures or tables would be generated based on the selections of users.

In the subsection of figure, users could select the country, the scope of months, or a specific month they want to observe. The top figure would display the total trend of a selected country in the selected months. Three lines would be shown in the figure, which represents the total confirmed cases, total death, and total recovered cases, respectively. The default range of months would be from January to October 2020. While the bottom figure shows the fluctuation of those three cases within a month. In the subsection of table, users could create a table by selecting a country and the frequency of the cases, which is monthly or daily. In addition, users could decide the level of the data, which means users could choose country-based or province-based data for creating the table.

The last section of citation lists the data source, packages, and references used in the Shiny app, which provide the chance of reproducibility for users who want to reproduce or update the app.

Self Review

The good points of the app

Firstly, the paragraphs of structure in the subsection of explanation should not be seen as wordy because it provides users a better understand of components of the app and help them get familiar with the app.

Secondly, the app provides multiple choices for users to further explore the situation of COVID-19. The subsection of figure allows users to select either a range of months or a specific month, which not only helps users gain an overview of the general trend of COVID-19 but also provides a chance to users to investigate the situation within a specific month. Meanwhile, users could choose a month by clicking the point in the general trend figure directly, which would be more convenient. In the subsection of table, the app allows users to observe either the cases of a country or a province in the frequency of monthly or daily, which would help users analyse COVID-19 comprehensively. Meanwhile, users could filter or search the information in the table.

Besides, the format of the app is unified. In the interactive subsection, all the selection bars are placed on the left side of the page, while the respondent figures or table are placed on the right-hand side. Besides, the format of that two figures is also consistent, like the same title size, and the same colour of the types of COVID-19 cases in both figures.

Furthermore, the title and the explanation of each figure or table could be altered automatically based on the choices of users. That could be helpful for users to understand the contents of each figure and table by the title and the explanations because the title and explanations are consistent with the choices of users.

At last, there are two buttons below each figure and table, which are guide and output. The guide button shows the steps of creating the corresponding figure or table, which would be helpful for users to create the figure or table easily. While the output button explains the components of the figures and table, as well as their contents.

The points that need improvements

Firstly, a picture showing the structure of the app would be inserted in the subsection of explanation to improve the illustration, rather than the literal statements only. Secondly, the size of characters in the selection bars could be increased to make them clearer. Thirdly, the in-text citations should be added in any explanation parts to help users gain associations with the supporting materials, included referencing the figure, table, section, and the data source.

While, an important point that needs to be improved is the illustration of each diagram and table, as what is available is inadequate. A paragraph explaining the trends and variations in the chart and the contents of the table should be added, which would help to explain the outputs of the figures and table.

At last, the original dataset of this app should be enlarged, which should contain more data from countries.

Some things that would like to add

Because the subsection of figure is used to display the trend of COVID-19 by diagrams. By considering how to inspire users to select a country or provide users a more intuitive sense of the general situation, a map of the world should be placed on the sidebar panel. This map would show the level of confirmed cases by colours and highlight the included countries of the dataset only. Meanwhile, the map would be a click plotly and users could choose a country by clicking the country on the map directly.

Besides, the subsection of table provides a chance for users to investigate the situation of a province in a country. A map of the country would be added in the sidebar panel to show the total confirmed cases of each province in a country by colours, which would also provide an intuitive sense of the COVID-19 situation. The map would popup when users select province-based data, and users could click a province in the map to get the corresponding table.

The limitations that prevent from adding new things

Although some new things are discussed, they did not be added to the app yet due to the limitation in data. Firstly, the original dataset is incomplete. Some data of provinces are missing in the dataset, and not all countries have provincial data. Secondly, the limitation of latitude and longitude of all provinces would also make the map of a country absent. Besides, adding the in-text citations in the Shiny app is not finished yet due to limitations of the technology of the creator, and it would be solved later.

Acknowledgement

This Shiny app has been published in the service of ShinyApps.io, you could check the app here. (The app might be sleeping because of the limitation of active time of the free account, therefore you might not run the app.)

The programming language used to write the self reflection is R (4.0.2) (R Core Team 2020).

References

R Core Team. 2020. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria: R Foundation for Statistical Computing. https://www.R-project.org/.

item.title: COVID-19 situations of Japan
item.description:
Introduction

Iwasaki and Grubaugh (2020) indicates that although Japan has a dense and aging population, it still reported low cases of COVID-19 infection in the first few months of the COVID-19 outbreak, compared with other countries. However, according to the latest COVID-19 report from the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan, Japan has experienced the second outbreak of COVID-19 from July 2020 (Ministry of Health and Welfare (2020)). And it is more serious than the first one. Therefore, this post will focus on the COVID-19 cases of Japan.

Data description

For exploring the COVID-19 situations of Japan, the post has used the COVID-19 data from the package called coronavirus. This package is from the Github repository owned by Rami Krispin, which could find all information related to this package from Github. By glimpsing this data, there are 175055 observations and 7 variables. Based on the help page of the coronavirus package, Krispin and Byrnes (2020) indicate the variables are in the following table 1:

Table 1: Description of variables in coronavirus data
Variable Class Description
date Date The format of date is YYYY-MM-DD
province character Name of province or state, if provided
country character Name of country or region
lat numeric Latitude of center of geographic region
long numeric Longitude of center of geographic region
type character Type of cases (confirmed, death, recovered)
cases integer Number of cases on given date

Because this post will focus on the cases of Japan, the filter function will be used to filter the data which makes the data only include Japanâs cases. Besides, because the types of COVID-19 cases are all contained in the same column, the function call pivot_wider will be applied to change the position of type as a variable rather than value.

Data story

Table 2: Summary table of COVID-19 cases in Japan
year month monthly confirmed monthly death monthly recovered cumulative confirmed cumulative death cumulative recovered
2020 1 15 0 1 15 0 1
2020 2 230 6 31 245 6 32
2020 3 2010 61 392 2255 67 424
2020 4 12029 414 2036 14284 481 2460
2020 5 2467 417 11882 16751 898 14342
2020 6 1864 74 2116 18615 972 16458
2020 7 17619 36 8316 36234 1008 24774
2020 8 32162 290 31564 68396 1298 56338

In order to explore the COVID-19 situations of Japan and identify the second outbreak situation, a summary table has been generated to support the following explanation. Table 2 indicates the monthly cases and cumulative cases of Japan from the first patient have been confirmed to the end of August 2020. Based on table 2, there were little cases in the first three month in Japan, which were only 2255 total cases and just account for 3.3% of the total confirmed cases. The first outbreak happened in April of 2020, which reported 12029 cases increased in this month, and the total cases have jumped to 14284 cases. The confirmed cases of April have increased 433.44% compared with the first three month total confirmed cases. Fortunately, the monthly confirmed cases of May and June all gradually decreased, and the total confirmed cases have slowly increased. However, May has reported the highest mortality among the eight months. There were 417 death cases in May, and it even three cases higher than that of the first outbreak, which was 414 cases. The reason might because the outbreak in April resulted in high confirmed cases so that led to the highest mortality in May. But, fortunately, the monthly recovered cases in May was 11882, and the cumulative recovered cases have reached to 14342, which accounted for 85.62% of the cumulative confirmed cases. And the recovery rate of June has reached to 88.41%.

However, because of the gradual return to works or the consciousness of defenses for COVID-19 of people may already be worn down. Japan also experienced the same second COVID-19 outbreak like other countries. The monthly confirmed cases of July have recorded at 17619, which increased 845.23% over June. Furthermore, August has recorded the highest monthly confirmed cases within eight months, which were 32162 cases. Such high monthly cases have contributed to the dramatic increase in cumulative confirmed cases of August which were 68396. And the monthly confirmed rate of August has accounted for almost a half among the total cases in eight months, which was 47.02%. Fortunately, there were only 36 death cases and 290 death cases in July and August, respectively. In addition, the recovered cases in July and August were also high, which were 8316 and 31564 cases, respectively. Finally, there are 82.37% of patients have reported as recovery at the end of August. That should be good news for Japan.

Interactive table

For helping the readers to better realise the COVID-19 situation of Japan. An interactive table has been created for the readers to explore the data of COVID-19 in Japan. Please refer to the following Figure 1.

Figure 1: The interactive table of COVID-19 situations in Japan

Conclusion

Many countries have experienced the second COVID-19 outbreak nowadays, as well as Japan. Everyone still needs to keep their consciousness of defense this pandemic. Furthermore, hoping the novel coronavirus vaccine will come out as soon as possible, as well as there is no increasing trend of confirmed cases in Japan.

Acknowledgement

COVID-19 situations of Japan

This post is used for exploring the situations of COVID-19 in Japan.

Data source

The data come from the coronavirus package in Github of Rami Krispin. You can browse the related information of coronavirus package by this link.

You have two ways to download the coronavirus package.

CRAN version

Try the command:

install.packages(“coronavirus”)

Github version

Try the command:

install.packages(“devtools”)

devtools::install_github(“RamiKrispin/coronavirus”)

P.S. You need to install the devtools package first, if you already have this package, please ignore it.

Data refresh

To refresh the data, please try:

library(coronavirus)

update_dataset()

Or you can use the Covid19R project data standard format to pull the data, please try:

new_object <- refresh_coronavirus_jhu()
